Graphical abstract The design of carrier-free recyclable catalysts is a key objective yet challenging task in modern catalysis. Here, we present the self-assembly of a nitrogen and phosphine-containing ligand (L) with RhI precusor to form a supramolecular assembly framework, (RhI 2L2)n·X, as confirmed by NMR, ESI-MS and X-ray crystallographic analysis. This RhI supramolecular assembly framework can partially dissolve in solution at high temperatures and fully recover at room temperature, facilitated by π-π, C–H···π and electrostatic interactions, thereby adopting the merits of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. The inherent coordination mode of RhI 2L2 enables this RhI supramolecular assembly framework to serve as an effective catalyst for promoting the hydroformylation and hydrosilylation of alkenes, with its practicality further demonstrated in a continuous-flow mini-plant, kilogram-scale hydroformylation of Fischtropsch C8 alkene, affording a turnover number of 1.27 × 105 over a 100-hour recycling period. In-situ high-pressure FTIR and DFT calculation elucidate the role of nitrogen and the dynamic evolution of catalytic resting state in the presence of syngas and alkene. Keywords Supramolecular assembly framework Alkene functionalization Carrier-free recyclable catalyst Reversibly binding CO Hydroformylation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The precise design and construction of catalysts is a fundamental focus in catalysis science, serving as a pivotal technology for advancing chemical processes to convert feedstocks into value-added products [1–3]. While homogeneous metal catalysts have garnered extensive attention due to their exceptional tunability in activity and selectivity, a primary challenge lies in the separation and recovery of these often costly catalysts [4–6]. In response to these challenges, innovative materials have been developed to covalently anchor homogeneous catalysts onto solid supports, [7–10] such as zeolites, [11,12] metal oxides, [13,14] and porous polymers, [15,16] incorporating the inherent advantages of homogeneous catalysts into heterogeneous catalytic systems. Consequently, the ongoing pursuit of new sustainable catalytic systems, which combines the merits of both heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis, remains a key objective in modern catalysis. In recent years, the rapid development of supramolecular chemistry has provided an alternative platform for the modular design of recycling catalysts [17–21]. One common approach is to immobilize homogenous catalysts onto host materials by non-covalent interactions, such as hydrogen bonding, [22–25] π-π stacking, [26–29] electrostatic interactions, [30–33] and other supramolecular interactions [34–37]. Furthermore, the self-assembly of supramolecular gels incorporating catalytically active metal complexes [38–41] or coordination cages [42–45] represents an additional elegant strategy for catalyst recovery [46–48]. These catalytic systems frequently display good selectivity, high efficiency, and robust recyclability of catalysts. Despite these advances, the development of more sustainable recyclable catalysts without the need for additional supporting materials remains a challenge and relatively elusive. An ideal approach for designing carrier-free recyclable catalysts is to harness the advantages of both homogeneous and heterogeneous phases. For example, catalysts can be designed to dissolve and form a homogeneous solution in response to specific stimuli, such as temperature, and subsequently recover in a heterogeneous form after the catalytic transformation. Supramolecular assembly frameworks (SAF), [49] formed through the assembly of metal ions and ligands, can adopt various packing models in the solid state, controlled by counterions and/or non-covalent interactions between each individual structure [50]. This would allow for the regulation of solubility in the solution, thus enabling the recycling of catalysts. Rhodium complex was chosen to demonstrate the proof-of-concept, taking into account its substantial contributions to industrial processes and its high cost. Here, we present a supramolecular assembly framework comprising an RhI 2L2 unit, formed through the self-assembly of BiPyPhos (L) with RhI, which efficiently catalyzes both the hydroformylation and hydrosilylation of a wide range of alkenes. This RhI SAF can partially dissolve under high temperature and crystallize in a self-replication manner through π-π, C–H···π, and electrostatic interactions at room temperature, enabling homogeneous catalysis and heterogeneous recycling of the precious rhodium catalysts with complete rhodium reclamation ( Fig. 1 A). After ten runs, the RhI 2L2 complex maintains high catalytic performance while retaining its structural integrity. Importantly, this catalyst displayed long-term stability in a continuous-flow hydroformylation of C8 alkene, with a turnover number of 1.27 × 105 over a 100-hour recycling period. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Synthesis of (RhI 2L2)n·X A 25 mL double-necked flask was charged with L (BiPyPhos) (0.10 mmol, 55.20 mg), Rh(acac)(CO)2 (0.10 mmol, 25.80 mg), and perchloric acid zinc hydrate (0.12 mmol, 44.70 mg). The mixture was sealed and degassed by N2. Subsequently, anhydrous and deoxygenated CH3CN (5 mL) was added and the mixture was stirred at room temperature to give a clear yellow solution. After heated at 60 °C for 10 h, a yellow precipitate was formed. The supernatant was filtered and the solid was washed with degassed Et2O (3 × 5 mL) and dried under vacuum to provide 53.50 mg of RhI 2L2·ClO4 as a yellow solid (71 % yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, Acetonitrile‑d3 ) δ 9.23 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 4H), 8.27 – 8.19 (m, 8H), 7.68 – 7.61 (m, 12H), 7.38 (dd, J = 7.8, 5.4 Hz, 4H), 7.29 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 4H), 7.04 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 4H), 6.76 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 8H), 6.44 – 6.36 (m, 8H), 3.51 (m, 4H), 2.78 (m, 4H). 31P{1H} NMR (162 MHz, Acetonitrile‑d3 ) δ 57.34 (d, J Rh-P = 175.0 Hz). ESI-MS spectrum of RhI 2L2 in CH3CN. ESI-MS (m/z): 655.0940 (calc. for 655.0939). Following the same procedure, RhI 2L2·OTf, RhI 2L2·BF4, RhI 2L2·BPh4, and RhI 2L2·PTA were also prepared by using their corresponding sodium salts instead of Zn(ClO4)2. 2.2 Synthesis of RhI 2(CO)2L2 The autoclave was charged with 10 mL anhydrous and deoxygenated CH3CN solution of RhI 2L2·ClO4 (0.02 mmol, 30.20 mg). The autoclave was sealed, flushed by CO three times and pressurized with 40 bar CO. After heated at 80 °C for 4 h, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature and the pressure was released. The suspension was centrifuged, and the solid was washed with Et2O (3 × 5 mL) and dried in vacuum to give 28.50 mg of RhI 2(CO)2L2·ClO4 as an orange solid (91 % yield). 31P{1H} NMR (162 MHz, Acetonitrile‑d3 ) intricate AB pattern at 41.16 (dd, 1J Rh-P = 131.2 Hz, 2J P-P = 45.4 Hz), 39.65 (dd, 1J Rh-P = 131.2 Hz, 2J P-P = 47.0 Hz) and 32.05 (dd, 1J Rh-P = 128.8 Hz, 2J P-P = 42.1 Hz), 30.32 (dd, 1J Rh-P = 128.8 Hz, 2J P-P = 43.7 Hz). ESI-MS spectrum of RhI 2(CO)2L2 in CH3CN. ESI-MS (m/z): 683.0982 (calc. for RhI 2(CO)2L2 683.0883). 2.3 Synthesis of RhI(CO)(Bpy)(Bisbi)·ClO4 A 50 mL double-necked flask was charged with 2,2′-bipyridine (Bpy, 0.10 mmol, 15.60 mg), 2,2′-bis(diphenylphosphinomethyl)-1,1′-biphenyl (Bisbi, 0.10 mmol, 55.00 mg), Rh(acac)(CO)2 (0.10 mmol, 25.80 mg), and sodium perchlorate (0.12 mmol, 14.60 mg). The mixture was sealed and degassed by N2. Subsequently, anhydrous and deoxygenated EtOH (10 mL) was added and the mixture was stirred at room temperature to give a clear yellow solution. After heated at 60 °C for 10 h, a yellow precipitate was formed. The supernatant was filtered and the solid was washed with degassed Et2O (3 × 5 mL) and dried under vacuum to provide 65.50 mg of RhI(CO)(Bpy)(Bisbi)·ClO4 as a yellow solid (70 % yield). 31P{1H} NMR (162 MHz, Acetonitrile‑d3 ) AB system centered at 35.47 (dd, 1J Rh-P = 134.5 Hz, 2J P-P = 294.0 Hz) and 19.12 (dd, 1J Rh-P = 137.7 Hz, 2J P-P = 294.0 Hz). 2.4 Catalysts characterization 1H NMR and 31P{1H} NMR spectra were collected using a Bruker 400 MHz AVA spectrometer at 25 °C unless otherwise noted. Signal multiplicity is reported using the following abbreviations: s = singlet, d = doublet, t = triplet, q = quartet, sep = septet, dt = doublet of triplets, and m = multiplet. All measurements were carried out at room temperature unless otherwise stated. High resolution mass spectra (HRMS) were obtained with a Shimadzu (LCMS-IT-TOF). The data are given as mass units per charge (m/z) and intensities of signals are given in brackets. UV–Vis absorption spectra were recorded on UV-3600 spectrophotometer from SHIMADZU Corporation. Infrared spectra were collected using a Shimadzu IRTracer-100, with a high signal-to-noise ratio of 60000:1 and a resolution of 0.25 cm−1. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were performed by Thermo Scientific Apreo S. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were collected under a N2 atmosphere over the temperature range 25–600 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min using a Mettler Toledo Star TGA/DSC. Inductively Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES) analysis of Rh leaching was performed with the PerkinElmer OPTIMA8000. 2.5 Hydroformylation reaction All hydroformylation reactions were conducted in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer. After loading a certain amount of catalysts (RhI 2L2)n·X, substrate alkene and solvent toluene, the autoclave was sealed and purged with syngas for four times, and then pressurized with syngas to the desired pressure and heated to the preset temperature for a specified time. After the reaction was stopped, the autoclave was immediately cooled to room temperature and vented. After centrifuge and filtration, the filtrate was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC-FID, Agilent 7890B equipped with a KB-1 column). The recovered (RhI 2L2)n·X by filtration was added into the autoclave which equipped with another portion of substrate and solvent to start the second run. The fresh (RhI 2L2)n·X was used in run 1, and the recovered catalyst from previous run was reused in next runs 2–10. The reaction conditions: 1.0 × 10−5 mol (RhI 2L2)n·X (catalyst), 1.0 × 10−2 mol alkene (substrate), substrate/catalyst = 1000/1, 3 mL toluene (solvent), 800 rpm, 40 bar (CO/H2 = 1/1), 80 °C, 6 h. 2.6 Hydrosilylation reactions All hydrosilylation reactions were conducted in a pre-dried Schlenk tube (10 mL), adding the (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 catalyst (1.90 mg). Subsequently, alkenes (1.00 mmol), dimethyl(phenyl)silane (1.20 mmol) and toluene (1 mL) were injected into Schlenk tube, then the reaction was stirred under 80 °C for 12 h. After the reaction, the mixture was simply centrifuged and filtrated. The product phase was purified by preparative thin-layer chromatography on silica gel to furnish the desired product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of RhI SAF catalyst A nitrogen and phosphine-containing ligand, 3,3′-bis((diphenylphosphanyl)methyl)-2,2′-bipyridine (BiPyPhos or L for short), [51] bearing two N-donors and two P-donors reacted with RhI(acac)(CO)2 in presence of Zn(ClO4)2 in CH3CN at 60 °C for 10 h, giving rise to a RhI complex ( Fig. 1 A ). Side product Zn(acac)2 was successfully removed by washing the crude product with diethyl ether. A RhI 2L2 composition was confirmed by electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS, Fig. S4 ). In the 1H diffusion-ordered spectroscopy (DOSY) spectrum of RhI 2L2 complex, a uniform diffusion coefficient was observed for all peaks, indicating the presence of a single complex (Fig. 1B and Fig. S3 ). Evidence of P-donor coordination was obtained from the 31P{1H} NMR spectra (Fig. 1 C), showing a doublet signal at 57.8 ppm (d, J Rh-P = 174.7 Hz) resulting from the Rh-P coupling. X-ray quality crystals of RhI 2L2·ClO4 were obtained by slow vapor diffusion of hexane into the acetone solution of this complex. The solid-state structure of RhI 2L2·ClO4 adopts a D2 -symmetric helical configuration, in which two Rh centers are bridged by two ligands ( Fig. 1 A, middle). Each RhI center adopts a square planar geometry, surrounded by two N-donors and two P-donors. The RhI···RhI distance is 4.7 Å, indicating the absence of RhI···RhI interactions [52–54]. The observed π-π stacking interactions (3.5 Å) between the phenyl rings of intramolecular PPh2 groups contribute to the formation of the robust RhI 2L2 structure. The RhI 2L2·ClO4 crystallizes in a P-1 space group, composing of twelve RhI 2L2 units distributed across three layers, as shown in the packing model ( Fig. 1A, right). In this arrangement, four RhI 2L2 units form a layer through extensive C–H···π interactions, while the layers are stacked non-covalently via electrostatic interactions between cationic RhI 2L2 and anionic ClO4, as well as C–H···π interactions. The unique stacking model observed here may suppress the dynamic nature of the metal–organic complex, making it less prone to disassembly under harsh conditions and more amenable to crystallization [50]. Consequently, the RhI 2L2 complexes readily crystallized, forming well-organized cuboid supramolecular crystalline catalysts (RhI 2L2)n (Fig. 1D). Other perchlorate salts were also tested as additives, including Fe(ClO4)3, Cu(ClO4)2, Mg(ClO4)2, NaClO4 and TBATClO4 (TBAT = tetrabutylammonium). Of these, all metal salts resulted in RhI 2L2·ClO4, as confirmed by 31P{1H} NMR spectra ( Fig. S13 ). However, TBATClO4 did not give the desired RhI complex, but yielded the oxidation of BiPyPhos. These observations indicate that the metal salt is essential for ligand exchange to remove the chelating acetylacetonate and the coordination of Rh and L also protect the ligand from oxidation. Additionally, various counteranions, such as OTf, BPh4, BF4, PTA (PTA = phosphotungstate), and ClO4, were screened to investigate the generality of this self-assembly strategy in forming (RhI 2L2)n·X complexes by adding their corresponding sodium salts instead of Zn(ClO4)2. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) again revealed well-crystalized cuboid (Fig. 1 E-G), with their structures confirmed by 1H and 31P{1H} NMR spectra ( Figs. S5–S12 ). Single crystal structure of RhI 2L2·BF4 also exhibits a similar crystal structure and packing model ( Scheme S2 ). 3.2 Responsive to temperature and reversibly binding CO UV/Vis spectroscopy was employed to study the temperature-responsive solubility of RhI 2L2·ClO4 in toluene ( Fig. 2 A). Crystallized solid (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 was subjected to toluene at 25 °C. As the temperature increased, a peak (300–360 nm) corresponding to π–π* transitions emerged, suggesting the partial dissolution of the solid and the homogeneous formation of RhI 2L2 in toluene. The solubility of RhI 2L2·ClO4 in toluene at 80 °C was measured to be 0.1 ppm using an inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Figs. S18, S19 ). Upon cooling back to 25 °C, the solid-state (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 was fully recovered (Fig. 2A). It is worth noting here that no changes in 1H and 31P{1H} NMR were observed at higher temperatures, indicating that RhI 2L2 retains its structural integrity without disassembly ( Figs. S14–S17 ). In addition, the RhI complex displayed good thermal stability in the solid state ( Fig. S20 ), with a decomposition temperature of approximately 310 °C. Furthermore, it exhibited robust air stability in both solid and solution states, including in solvents such as toluene, acetone and acetonitrile, for a duration of 60 days without decomposition ( Figs. S21–S22 ). The observed temperature-dependent solubility here, along with the good stability, would benefit the catalyst recycling in catalytic transformations. The unsaturated 16-electron nature of RhI vertex within RhI 2L2 suggests the potential for catalytic capability of such RhI SAF, [55–57] prompting us to investigate its reactivity with CO (Fig. 2B). Upon activation by 40 bar of CO in an autoclave at 80 °C for 4 h, a characteristic carbonyl band at 2007 cm−1 appeared in the IR spectra ( Fig. 2B), consistent with the 31P{1H} NMR spectra showing an AB pattern at 41.2 and 32.1 ppm at the expense of free RhI 2L2 ( Fig. 2B). ESI-MS confirmed the formation of the RhI 2(CO)2L2 complex ( Fig. S25 ). Further heating under air led to the release of CO and the recovery of RhI 2L2, which was confirmed by IR and 31P{1H} NMR spectra (Fig. 2B). Despite numerous attempts, we were unsuccessful in growing single crystals of RhI 2(CO)2L2. However, in control experiments, mixing 2,2′-bipyridine (Bpy) and 2,2′-bis(diphenylphosphinomethyl)-1,1′-biphenyl (Bisbi) with Rh(acac)(CO)2 and sodium perchlorate gave X-ray quality crystals of the mononuclear RhI(CO)(Bpy)(Bisbi) complex, with the RhI center adopting a pseudo-trigonal bipyramidal geometry ( Scheme S4 ), where the P-Rh-P bite angle was bent to 151.15°. Such a distorted configuration may lead to a different packing arrangement, resulting in micromorphology changes of the catalyst. Indeed, the micromorphology of (RhI 2L2)n became disordered upon binding CO and reordered upon releasing CO, as shown by SEM ( Fig. S23 ). 3.3 Hydroformylation of alkenes Encouraged by the reversible binding of CO to RhI 2L2 and its temperature-dependent solubility, we turned to investigate its catalytic performance and recyclability in industrially appealing hydroformylation reaction, [58,59] which produces over 10 million tons of value-added aldehydes annually. (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 was firstly employed to promote the hydroformylation of various alkenes, in toluene at 80 °C under H2 and CO (1/1, 40 bar), and moderate to excellent aldehydes yields (56–97 %) were generally obtained, as shown in Fig. 3 A and Table S1 . Moderate n/iso (n-aldehyde to total iso-aldehydes) ratios 0.45–0.99 was observed under low P/Rh (2/1) at 4 MPa. Remarkably, (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 successfully facilitated the high-yield conversion of long-chain C8–C18 alkenes into their corresponding aldehydes (80–91 %), which are highly demanded raw materials of new plasticizers, surfactants, and lubricants. (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 worked well in the hydroformylation of styrene (93 %, Fig. 3 A, Table S1 , entry 9), and afforded lower yield for the hydroformylation of steric hindered 1,1-disubstituted alkene α-methylstyrene (56 %, Fig. 3 A, Table S1 , entry 10) [60,61]. Notably, steric effect also influences regioselectivity [62]. Styrene may form η3-allyl-Rh intermediates favoring the formation of branched aldehydes, while, α-methylstyrene favors η1-allyl-Rh coordination, resulting in excellent selectivity for linear aldehyde (3-phenylbutanal, > 99 %). After the reactions, simply cooling the reaction systems to room temperature and performing a straightforward filtration process could achieve the recycling of the Rh catalyst. It is interesting that the recovered (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 demonstrates similar catalytic behavior to the fresh one in the hydroformylation of 1-dodecene ( Fig. S29 ). Notably, the (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 catalyst maintained both consistent reactivity and structural integrity for the hydroformylation of various alkenes after multiple recycling cycles ( Figs. 3C, S30 ), without decreased yields being observed ( Figs. 3B, S38–S46 ). After 10 runs, the Rh leaching was calculated to be 3.47 wt% for (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 ( Table S1 ). Similarly, (RhI 2L2)n·PTA, (RhI 2L2)n·OTf and (RhI 2L2)n·BF4 also exhibited excellent catalytic capability and recyclability for the hydroformylation of 1-dodecene ( Figs. S34–S37 ). The (RhI 2L2)n·PTA exhibited lower Rh leaching of 1.36 wt% ( Table S2 ), while (RhI 2L2)n·BPh4 yielded only 70 % tridecanal ( Fig. S37 ), and exhibited significantly higher Rh leaching of 27.0 wt% after 10 runs ( Table S3 ). We attribute this to the bulky nature of BPh4 hindering alkene coordination to Rh during the catalytic process, as well as the better solubility of (RhI 2L2)n·BPh4 in toluene at room temperature (Fig. S19). Interestingly, the leaching part due to dissolution could be completely reclaimed through vacuum evaporation, confirmed by 1H and 31P{1H} NMR spectra ( Figs. S47–S48 ). 3.4 Reaction nature and mechanism studies To determine whether the RhI SAF functions as a homogeneous or heterogeneous catalyst in the hydroformylation reactions, we conducted a series of control experiments. Firstly, during the hydromation of 1-dodecene, the solid state (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 was removed by hot filtration after 1 h. The resulting filtrate, containing homogeneous RhI 2L2, 1-dodecene, and 17 % tridecanals, was then subjected to identical conditions for an additional 5 h, yielding similar results to that of the one-pot reaction using (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 ( Fig. S28 ). Furthermore, a mercury poisoning study was conducted. Hg(0) would deactivate the rhodium nanoparticles. Consequently, nanoparticle-derived activity would decrease upon with the presence of mercury [62,63]. In this study, mercury did not inhibit the hydroformylation of 1-dodecene, as the yield of tridecanals was 89 %, comparable to the standard hydroformylation yield (90 %) ( Fig. S28 ). These reults indicated the RhI SAF partially dissolves under standard conditions and functions as a homogeneous catalyst, which as has been disclosed by Smith with Rh catalyst precursors [63–65]. In order to gain an insight into the catalytic mechanism, in-situ high-pressure (HP)-FTIR and HP-NMR spectroscopic characterizations were conducted on the solution of (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 in CH3CN or CD3CN. HP-FTIR experiments of (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 in CH3CN were performed under 30 bar of syngas at room temperature and 80 °C. The spectra revealed a transition of the RhI 2L2 catalyst to the active species once syngas was introduced at room temperature, as a new vibrational band was observed at 2069 cm−1 (Fig. 4 A), which was different from the vibration of RhI 2(CO)2L2 (2007 cm−1) and could be belonged to the ν(Rh-CO) of [HRh(P)2(CO)] species with the dissociation of nitrogen atom [57,66]. Interestingly, two new bands at 2139 cm−1 and 2010 cm−1 appeared rapidly over the time, those could be assigned to ν(Rh-CO) stretching vibration of [HRh(P)2(CO)2]. After addition of 1-dodecene, the carbonyl region of [HRh(P)2(CO)] and [HRh(P)2(CO)2] were also observed in the HR-FTIR spectra, but the ν(Rh-CO) vibration signal at 2010 cm−1 was slightly decreased with an additional broad shoulder detected at 1999 cm−1 (Fig. 4B), which was probably ascribed to the ν(Rh-CO) of [HRh(P)2(CO)(alkene)] originating from the dissociation of a Rh-CO bond followed by 1-dodecene coordination [57,66]. These results reveals that the catalytically active species might be an equilibrium of [HRh(P)2(CO)], [HRh(P)2(CO)2] and [HRh(P)2(CO)(alkene)] species under hydroformylation conditions. HP-NMR experiments of (RhI 2L2)n·ClO4 in CD3CN were performed under 10 bar of syngas at 80 °C. Unfortunately, the signal of rhodium hydride was not detected probably due to low concentration or low pressure [67]. Beller disclosed that N-pyridyl moiety might function as a proton shuttle to facilitate the formation of catalytically active species for carbonylation reaction [68,69]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to understand the contribution of N-pyridyl moiety in hydroformylation. Two plausible pathways were suggested [70,71]. One pathway involves pyridine-N-assisted heterolytic H2 splitting, followed by protonolysis of the acyl-RhI key intermediate, while the other proceeds through the H2 oxidative addition to RhI species and subsequent reductive elimination of the acyl-RhIII-H complex ( Supplementary Information , Section 6.9). Although both pathways are feasible, the pyridine-N-assisted pathway exhibits significantly lower Gibbs free energy, with −16.2 kcal/mol for the protonolysis of the acyl-RhI species, [72–74] thereby promoting product release and the regeneration of RhI 2(CO)2L2. 3.5 Stability studies for industrial hydroformylation The hydroformylation of alkenes generally requires high temperatures, with even higher temperatures needed for the distillation of the desired aldehydes, particularly for the long-chain C8–C18 alkenes [75,76]. As such, we proceeded to evaluate the thermal stability of RhI 2L2 catalyst for long-term use in a continuous-flow mini-plant setup on a kilogram-scale (Fig. 5 A). The investigation was carried out with a mixture of substrates, similar to an industrial process that rarely use single components in large-scale hydroformylation. In a 100-hour continuous operation, RhI 2L2, loaded at 30 ppm, effectively catalyzed the hydroformylation of Fischer-Tropsch (FT) C8 alkene, with a mean conversion of 97 %, an average selectivity of 84 % for nonanal, and an average space–time yield (STY) of 72 kg·m−3·h−1. A total turnover number of 1.27 × 105 was achieved without the addition of any extra catalyst or ligand, demonstrating the exceptional long-term stability of the catalyst. This remarkable stability might be attributed to the inherent coordination mode of RhI 2L2. Although the Rh content in the product stream was measured around 100–140 ppb by atomic absorption spectroscopy, at 25-hour intervals throughout the 100-hour reaction period. This minimal leaching is primarily attributed to physical entrainment during product distillation rather than catalyst decomposition. Further leaching reduction will be pursued through separation unit optimization to minimize carry-over and anion exchange ([PTA]3- for ClO4 -) to strengthen electrostatic stabilization. 3.6 Hydrosilylation reactions The practicality of this RhI SAF was further demonstrated in the hydrosilylation reactions (Eq. 1), with moderate to good yields for the anti-Markovnikov hydrosilylation of terminal alkenes. However, internal alkenes showed no reactivity, likely due to steric hindrance. However, internal alkenes showed no reactivity, likely due to steric hindrance. 4 Conclusion The coordination-driven self-assembly of RhI 2L2 thus provides a general method to prepare a new class of carrier-free recyclable RhI catalysts. The unique packing model enables the RhI SAF to integrate the advantages of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis, as demonstrated by its high reactivity and robust recyclability in hydroformylation reactions. In-situ HP-FTIR reveals the presence of [HRh(P)2(CO)], [HRh(P)2(CO)2] and [HRh(P)2(CO)(alkene)] catalytic species under hydroformylation conditions. DFT calculation suggests that N-pyridyl moiety might facilitate the protonolysis of the acyl-RhI species and yield aldehyde product. Its long-term thermal stability was further demonstrated by a 100-hour continuous-flow mini-plant experiment, underlining its potential for application in industrially relevant chemical processes and laying the foundation for the future design of more sustainable carrier-free catalysts using a supramolecular self-assembly strategy. coredata.dc:description: The design of carrier-free recyclable catalysts is a key objective yet challenging task in modern catalysis. Here, we present the self-assembly of a nitrogen and phosphine-containing ligand (L) with RhI precusor to form a supramolecular assembly framework, (RhI 2L2)n·X, as confirmed by NMR, ESI-MS and X-ray crystallographic analysis. This RhI supramolecular assembly framework can partially dissolve in solution at high temperatures and fully recover at room temperature, facilitated by π-π, C–H···π and electrostatic interactions, thereby adopting the merits of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. The inherent coordination mode of RhI 2L2 enables this RhI supramolecular assembly framework to serve as an effective catalyst for promoting the hydroformylation and hydrosilylation of alkenes, with its practicality further demonstrated in a continuous-flow mini-plant, kilogram-scale hydroformylation of Fischtropsch C8 alkene, affording a turnover number of 1.27 × 105 over a 100-hour recycling period. In-situ high-pressure FTIR and DFT calculation elucidate the role of nitrogen and the dynamic evolution of catalytic resting state in the presence of syngas and alkene.
